abstract: Large hedge funds, which use extensive borrowing to magnify their returns, will be required to report detailed information on their holdings to federal regulators under a new rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
snippet: Large hedge funds, which use extensive borrowing to magnify their returns, will be required to report detailed information on their holdings to federal regulators under a new rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: Large hedge funds, which use extensive borrowing to magnify their returns, will be required to report detailed information on their holdings to federal regulators under a new rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday, Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports. The purpose of the annual disclosure is to give regulators the ability to monitor the risks that the funds pose to the overall financial system. Read more »

headline.main: S.E.C. Rule Lifts Lid on Hedge Funds
